title: For U.S. Businesses, a Time to Spend
sub_head: Despite uncertainty over course of pandemic and prospects for economy, many companies can’t help but invest
body:
Companies don’t know how big or long-lasting the economic rebound might be. But they need to gear up for it.
The Commerce Department reported Thursday that orders for durable goods—long-lasting items that run the gamut from sheet metal to shipping containers—rose 3.4% in January from December, putting them 4.5% above their level of a year earlier, before the Covid-19 crisis struck. That jump indicates that a powerful “bullwhip effect”, where businesses’ efforts to rebuild inventories ripple through the economy, has taken hold.
Orders for nondefense capital goods excluding aircraft—a closely watched proxy for capital spending—rose a more muted 0.5% in January from December. That was up 9.1% from a year earlier, however, and in the months ahead the demand for capital goods might only build.
In considering capital spending plans, businesses face a bit of a dilemma. The decline in new Covid cases in recent weeks, the vaccine rollout and the likelihood of another round of government relief suggest that sales could surge.
But by how much, and in what areas? It seems probable that services spending will really pick up as Americans return to more normal activities, so service-sector businesses need to prepare for that. Goods spending might soften as a result—or maybe not. Moreover, the release of pent-up demand could carry the economy through the end of the year, but what sort of legs the rebound might have after that is unclear.
